title: 103_s2254
content: The Act titled "Independent Nuclear Safety Board Act of 1994" is established for the purpose of ensuring nuclear safety. The Independent Nuclear Safety Board Act of 1994 establishes a board to investigate events at nuclear facilities regulated by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission that could impact public health and safety. The Independent Nuclear Safety Board Act of 1994 establishes a board to investigate events at nuclear facilities that could impact public health and safety. The board's responsibilities include reviewing and assessing the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's licensing and regulatory practices, recommending improvements, and informing Congress of findings and recommendations resulting from investigations. The Independent Nuclear Safety Board Act of 1994 establishes an independent nuclear safety board to investigate events at nuclear facilities that could impact public health and safety. The board's responsibilities include reviewing and assessing the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's practices, recommending improvements, and informing Congress of findings and recommendations from investigations. The Energy Reorganization Act of 1974 is amended to include the establishment of the Nuclear Safety Board. The Independent Nuclear Safety Board, established in 1994, consists of 3 members appointed by the President with Senate approval. Members must be experts in commercial nuclear energy and not more than 2 can be from the same political party. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Board members are appointed by the President with Senate approval and vacancies are filled in the same manner. Members cannot have significant financial relationships with entities regulated by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. The Chairperson and Vice Chairperson are designated by the President and may be reappointed. The Chairperson of the Board is the chief executive officer and is responsible for appointing and supervising personnel, organizing administrative units, and managing funds. The Chairperson can delegate these functions to other Board members or appropriate employees. The Vice Chairperson acts as Chairperson in their absence or vacancy. Board members serve 6-year terms, with initial members appointed for varying lengths by the President. The Board members serve 6-year terms and can be appointed to fill vacancies for the remainder of the term. The President can remove a member for inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance. Two members constitute a quorum for hearings, and the Board investigates events at licensed facilities. The Board investigates events at licensed facilities involving material regulated by the Commission that could adversely affect public health or safety. They may request the Commission to investigate and report findings in a timely manner. The Board may analyze the findings of the Commission after concluding an investigation to make its own conclusions and recommendations. The purpose of a Board investigation is to gather information about the event's circumstances and its implications for public health and safety, as well as to determine if the event is part of a pattern involving regulated material. The Board is tasked with analyzing operational data from facilities regulated by the Commission to identify potential risks to public health and safety. They provide recommendations for changes in licensing, safety regulations, and other regulatory policies as needed. The Board analyzes operational data from regulated facilities to identify safety issues, conducts special studies, and evaluates suggestions for improving safety measures. The Board analyzes operational data from regulated facilities to identify safety issues and makes recommendations to the Commission on specific measures to minimize adverse events affecting public health or safety. The Commission must respond to these recommendations within 120 days, detailing measures adopted and reasons for any inaction. The Board analyzes operational data from regulated facilities to identify safety issues and makes recommendations to the Commission. The recommendations are submitted to Congress, and reporting requirements are established for those involved with regulated facilities. The Board analyzes operational data from regulated facilities to identify safety issues and makes recommendations to the Commission. Reporting requirements may include classified material or safeguards information protected from disclosure under the Atomic Energy Act of 1954. Information received by the Board will be made available to the public as required by law. The Independent Safety Board Act of 1974 allows the Board to hold hearings, administer oaths, issue subpoenas, and compel witness testimony and evidence for the purpose of carrying out its duties. The Independent Safety Board Act of 1974 empowers the Board to issue subpoenas under the signature of the Chairperson or designated member, enforce witness attendance and evidence production nationwide, and administer oaths to witnesses. Any person who willfully neglects or refuses to testify or produce evidence in response to a subpoena issued by the Board may face a fine of up to $5,000, imprisonment for up to 180 days, or both. The Chairperson can certify the facts to the United States attorney for prosecution. The Board is required to issue periodic reports. The Board is mandated to issue periodic reports containing major investigation findings and recommendations to prevent nuclear events recurrence. These reports are accessible to Congress, government agencies, and interested parties upon request. The Board is authorized to hire staff and consultants to carry out its functions. The term "event" includes actions or failures by individuals or organizations. The Board is authorized to transfer functions and personnel from the Office for Analysis and Evaluation of Operational Data of the Commission to carry out its described functions. Authorization of appropriations is also provided. Authorization of $10,000,000 for fiscal years 1995 through 2000 to carry out the Board's functions, with termination set for September 30, 2000.
